# Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces

Byoungwoo Park1,
Jungwon Choi1,
Sungbin Lim2,3,
Juho Lee111footnotemark: 1

KAIST1, Korea University2, LG AI Research3

{bw.park, jungwon.choi, juholee}@kaist.ac.kr,

sungbin@korea.ac.krCo-corresponding Author

###### Abstract

Recent advancements in diffusion models and diffusion bridges primarily focus on finite-dimensional spaces, yet many real-world problems necessitate operations in infinite-dimensional function spaces for more natural and interpretable formulations.
In this paper, we present a theory of stochastic optimal control (SOC) tailored to infinite-dimensional spaces, aiming to extend diffusion-based algorithms to function spaces.
Specifically, we demonstrate how Doob’s hℎh-transform, the fundamental tool for constructing diffusion bridges, can be derived from the SOC perspective and expanded to infinite dimensions.
This expansion presents a challenge, as infinite-dimensional spaces typically lack closed-form densities.
Leveraging our theory, we establish that solving the optimal control problem with a specific objective function choice is equivalent to learning diffusion-based generative models.
We propose two applications: 1) learning bridges between two infinite-dimensional distributions and 2) generative models for sampling from an infinite-dimensional distribution.
Our approach proves effective for diverse problems involving continuous function space representations, such as resolution-free images, time-series data, and probability density functions.

## 1 Introduction

Stochastic Optimal Control (SOC) is designed to steer a noisy system toward a desired state by minimizing a specific cost function. This methodology finds extensive applications across various fields in science and engineering, including rate event simulation \[ [29](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib29 ""), [31](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib31 "")\], stochastic filtering and data assimilation \[ [43](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib43 ""), [65](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib65 ""), [49](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib49 "")\], non-convex optimization \[ [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib9 "")\], modeling population dynamics \[ [8](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib8 ""), [39](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib39 "")\]. SOC is also related to diffusion-based sampling methods that are predominant in machine learning literature. Specifically, if we choose the terminal cost of a control problem as the log density ratio between a target distribution and a simple prior distribution, solving the optimal control reduces to learning a diffusion-based generative models \[ [50](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib50 ""), [70](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib70 ""), [66](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib66 "")\] built upon the Schrödinger bridge problem \[ [48](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib48 ""), [12](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib12 "")\].

While SOC associated diffusion-based generative models have been well-established for finite-dimensional spaces \[ [5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib5 ""), [10](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib10 ""), [11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib11 ""), [41](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib41 "")\], their theoretical foundations and practical algorithms for infinite-dimensional spaces remain underexplored.
There is a growing interest in developing generative models in function spaces.
Examples include learning neural operators for partial differential equations (PDEs) \[ [36](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib36 ""), [35](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib35 ""), [33](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib33 "")\], interpreting images as discretized functions through implicit neural representations (INRs) \[ [56](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib56 ""), [19](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib19 "")\], and operating in function spaces for Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) \[ [58](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib58 ""), [67](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib67 "")\]. Models that operate in function spaces are more parameter-efficient as they avoid resolution-specific parameterizations.
In response to this demand, several extensions of diffusion-based generative models for infinite-dimensional function spaces have been proposed  \[ [47](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib47 ""), [37](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib37 ""), [28](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib28 ""), [38](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib38 ""), [22](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib22 ""), [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib3 "")\].
However, SOC theory for building diffusion bridges in function spaces is still demanding in the community of generative modeling.

To address these challenges, this work introduces an extension of SOC for diffusion bridges in infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces, particularly focusing on its applications in sampling problems.
Specifically, we demonstrate the idea of Doob’s hℎh transform \[ [52](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib52 ""), [13](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib13 "")\] can be derived from SOC theory and extend its formulation into Hilbert spaces.
Due to the absence of a density with respect to the Lebesgue measure in infinite-dimensional spaces, building a diffusion bridge between function spaces is a nontrivial task separated from the finite-dimensional cases \[ [46](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib46 ""), [54](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib54 "")\].
To this end, we propose a Radon-Nikodym derivative relative to a specified Gaussian reference measure in Hilbert space.
Leveraging the infinite-dimensional Doob’s hℎh transform and SOC, we then formulate diffusion bridge-based sampling algorithms in function spaces.

To demonstrate the applicability of our theory, we present learning algorithms for two representative problems.
First, we introduce an infinite-dimensional bridge-matching algorithm as an extension of previous methods \[ [46](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib46 ""), [54](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib54 "")\] into Hilbert spaces, which learns a generative model to bridge two distributions defined in function spaces.
As an example, we show that our framework can learn smooth transitions between two image distributions in a resolution-free manner.
Second, we propose a simulation-based Bayesian inference algorithm \[ [70](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib70 ""), [66](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib66 "")\] that operates in function space. Instead of directly approximating the target Bayesian posterior, our algorithm learns a stochastic transition from the prior to the posterior within the function space. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by inferring Bayesian posteriors of stochastic processes, such as Gaussian processes.
We summarize our contributions as follows:

- •


Based on the SOC theory, we derive the Doob’s hℎh-transform in Hilbert spaces. We propose a hℎh function as a Randon-Nikodym derivative with respect to a Gaussian measure in infinite-dimensional space.

- •


Based on the infinite-dimensional extension of the Doob’s hℎh transform, we present the diffusion bridge and simulation-based Bayesian inference algorithm in function spaces.

- •


We demonstrate our method for various real-world problems involving function spaces, including resolution-free image translation and posterior sampling for stochastic processes.


## 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges

In this section, we first present a brief introduction to the theory of stochastic optimal control (SOC) in infinite dimensions and the Verification Theorem (Lemma [2.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem1 "Lemma 2.1 (Verification Theorem). ‣ 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")), which is the key to understanding the theoretical connection between SOC and the diffusion bridges.
Then we propose Doob’s hℎh-transform in Hilbert spaces based on the SOC theory (Theorems [2.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem2 "Theorem 2.2 (Hopf-Cole Transform). ‣ 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") and [2.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem3 "Theorem 2.3 (Explicit Representation of ℎ). ‣ 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")).

### 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces

By using the dynamic programming \[ [20](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib20 "")\], we can solve the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation,

A proof of Theorem [2.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem3 "Theorem 2.3 (Explicit Representation of ℎ). ‣ 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") is based on \[ [16](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib16 ""), Chap. 10.3\]. Theorem [2.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem3 "Theorem 2.3 (Explicit Representation of ℎ). ‣ 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") states that the marginal distribution of certain classes of SDEs described in ( [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E1 "In Stochastic Differential Equations in Hilbert Spaces. ‣ 2.1 Preliminaries ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) has an explicit Radon-Nikodym density with respect to their invariant measure. Therefore, by the time-homogeneity of the process in ( [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E1 "In Stochastic Differential Equations in Hilbert Spaces. ‣ 2.1 Preliminaries ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")), it allows us to define the hℎh function explicitly:

### 2.4 Approximating path measures

Since the function hℎh is intractable for a general terminal cost G~~𝐺\\tilde{G} in ( [12](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E12 "In 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")), simulating the conditioned SDEs in ( [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E9 "In 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) requires some approximation techniques. As observed in Lemma [2.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem2 "Theorem 2.2 (Hopf-Cole Transform). ‣ 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces"), finding the function hℎh is equal to learning the control function α𝛼\\alpha such that ℙαsuperscriptℙ𝛼\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha} is equal to ℙ⋆:=ℙα⋆=ℙhassignsuperscriptℙ⋆superscriptℙsuperscript𝛼⋆superscriptℙℎ\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}:=\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha^{\\star}}=\\mathbb{P}^{h}. Therefore, with a parametrization α:=α​(⋅,θ)assign𝛼𝛼⋅𝜃\\alpha:=\\alpha(\\cdot,\\theta) the approximation can be done by neural network parameterization
i.e.,α⋆≈αθ⋆\\textit{i}.\\textit{e}.,\\alpha^{\\star}\\approx\\alpha^{\\theta^{\\star}} with local minimum θ⋆=arg​minθD(ℙα\|\|ℙ⋆)\\theta^{\\star}=\\operatorname\*{arg\\,min}\_{\\theta}D(\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}\|\|\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}), whereD(ℙα\|\|ℙ⋆)D(\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}\|\|\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}) is a divergence between ℙαsuperscriptℙ𝛼\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha} and ℙ⋆superscriptℙ⋆\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}. For example, the cost functional described in equation ( [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E3 "In 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) can be represented as relative-entropy loss Drel(ℙα\|\|ℙ⋆)=𝔼ℙα\[logd​ℙαd​ℙ⋆\]D\_{\\text{rel}}(\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}\|\|\\mathbb{P}^{\\star})=\\mathbb{E}\_{\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}}\\left\[\\log\\frac{d\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}}{d\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}}\\right\]111See Sec [A.5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#A1.SS5 "A.5 Deriving Divergence Between Path Measures ‣ Appendix A Appendix ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") for more details. Therefore, the training loss for θ𝜃\\theta can be estimated by first simulating the parameterized control path and then calculating ( [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E3 "In 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) for a specified cost functional R,G𝑅𝐺R,G. Moreover, if we can access to the ℙ⋆superscriptℙ⋆\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}, one can define the variational optimization \[ [62](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib62 "")\] where the loss is defined as cross-entropy loss Dcross(ℙα\|\|ℙ⋆)=𝔼ℙ⋆\[logd​ℙ⋆d​ℙα\]D\_{\\text{cross}}(\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}\|\|\\mathbb{P}^{\\star})=\\mathbb{E}\_{\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}}\\left\[\\log\\frac{d\\mathbb{P}^{\\star}}{d\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha}}\\right\].
See \[ [44](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib44 ""), [18](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib18 "")\] for more details about the approximation technique and other loss functions.

## 3 Simulating Diffusion Bridges in Infinite Dimensional Spaces

Leveraging the SOC theory within ℋℋ\\mathcal{H}, we show how our approach generalizes existing diffusion-based sampling methods. Specifically, incorporating the relation between controlled SDEs ( [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E2 "In 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) and conditioned SDEs ( [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E9 "In 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")), we introduce two learning algorithms that allow us to simulate various diffusion bridge-based sampling algorithms.

### 3.1 Infinite Dimensional Bridge Matching

In this section, our objective is to learn a control α𝛼\\alpha that yields ℙαsuperscriptℙ𝛼\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha} such that {𝐗tα}t∈\[0,T\]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐗𝛼𝑡𝑡0𝑇\\{\\mathbf{X}^{\\alpha}\_{t}\\}\_{t\\in\[0,T\]} satisfies μtα≈μt⋆subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝛼𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜇⋆𝑡\\mu^{\\alpha}\_{t}\\approx\\mu^{\\star}\_{t} for all pre-specified μt⋆subscriptsuperscript𝜇⋆𝑡\\mu^{\\star}\_{t} over the interval t∈\[0,T\]𝑡0𝑇t\\in\[0,T\]. Specifically, we assume that the end-point marginals μ0⋆subscriptsuperscript𝜇⋆0\\mu^{\\star}\_{0} and μT⋆subscriptsuperscript𝜇⋆𝑇\\mu^{\\star}\_{T} follow the laws of two data distributions π0subscript𝜋0\\pi\_{0} and πTsubscript𝜋𝑇\\pi\_{T}, respectively, and the intermediate marginals {μt⋆}t∈(0,T)subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜇⋆𝑡𝑡0𝑇\\{\\mu^{\\star}\_{t}\\}\_{t\\in(0,T)} are defined as a mixture of diffusion bridge paths. This learning problem is referred to as the Bridge Matching (BM) algorithm \[ [45](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib45 ""), [54](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib54 ""), [40](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib40 "")\] and can be expressed as a solution of the SOC problem structured as

### 3.2 Bayesian Learning in Function Space

In the previous section, we observed that by appropriately defining a terminal cost functional G𝐺G in ( [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E3 "In 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")), the SOC problem aligns with the sampling problem, where optimal control effectively steers the distribution from π0subscript𝜋0\\pi\_{0} to the target distribution πTsubscript𝜋𝑇\\pi\_{T}, where we can access samples from π0subscript𝜋0\\pi\_{0} and πTsubscript𝜋𝑇\\pi\_{T}. However, accessing samples from unknown target distribution πTsubscript𝜋𝑇\\pi\_{T} is generally not feasible. For instance, for a πTsubscript𝜋𝑇\\pi\_{T}, a posterior distribution over function. In this case, although direct samples from πTsubscript𝜋𝑇\\pi\_{T} are unattainable, its distributional representation is given as \[ [59](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib59 ""), [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib3 "")\]:

##### Objective Functional for Bayesian Learning.

Unlike problem in ( [16](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S3.E16 "In 3.1 Infinite Dimensional Bridge Matching ‣ 3 Simulating Diffusion Bridges in Infinite Dimensional Spaces ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) where we can access to the target path measure there target path measure ℙ⋆superscriptℙ⋆\\mathbb{P}^{\\star} directly, ℙ⋆superscriptℙ⋆\\mathbb{P}^{\\star} is not feasible since h​(t,𝐱)=𝔼ℙ​\[−d​πTd​μT​(𝐗T)\|𝐗t=𝐱\]ℎ𝑡𝐱subscript𝔼ℙdelimited-\[\]conditional𝑑subscript𝜋𝑇𝑑subscript𝜇𝑇subscript𝐗𝑇subscript𝐗𝑡𝐱h(t,\\mathbf{x})=\\mathbb{E}\_{\\mathbb{P}}\\left\[-\\frac{d\\pi\_{T}}{d\\mu\_{T}}(\\mathbf{X}\_{T})\|\\mathbf{X}\_{t}=\\mathbf{x}\\right\] has no closed-form in this case. Therefore, we will use the relative-entropy loss as our training loss function:

|     |     |     |     |

|  | ℒBayes​(θ)=Drel​(ℙαθ\|ℙ⋆)=𝔼ℙαθ​\[∫0T12​∥α​(s,𝐗sαθ;θ)∥ℋ02​𝑑s−log⁡d​πTd​μT​(𝐗Tαθ)\].subscriptℒBayes𝜃subscript𝐷relconditionalsuperscriptℙsuperscript𝛼𝜃superscriptℙ⋆subscript𝔼superscriptℙsuperscript𝛼𝜃delimited-\[\]superscriptsubscript0𝑇12superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝛼𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐗superscript𝛼𝜃𝑠𝜃subscriptℋ02differential-d𝑠𝑑subscript𝜋𝑇𝑑subscript𝜇𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐗superscript𝛼𝜃𝑇\\mathcal{L}\_{\\text{Bayes}}(\\theta)=D\_{\\text{rel}}(\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha^{\\theta}}\|\\mathbb{P}^{\\star})=\\mathbb{E}\_{\\mathbb{P}^{\\alpha^{\\theta}}}\\left\[\\int\_{0}^{T}\\frac{1}{2}\\left\\lVert\\alpha(s,\\mathbf{X}^{\\alpha^{\\theta}}\_{s};\\theta)\\right\\rVert\_{\\mathcal{H}\_{0}}^{2}ds-\\log\\frac{d\\pi\_{T}}{d\\mu\_{T}}(\\mathbf{X}^{\\alpha^{\\theta}}\_{T})\\right\]. |  | (24) |

The key difference from previous algorithms \[ [70](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib70 ""), [66](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib66 "")\] is that the Radon-Nikodym derivative d​πTd​μT​(𝐗Tα)𝑑subscript𝜋𝑇𝑑subscript𝜇𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝛼𝑇\\frac{d\\pi\_{T}}{d\\mu\_{T}}(\\mathbf{X}^{\\alpha}\_{T}) may not be well-defined on ℋℋ\\mathcal{H} due to the absence of the Lesbesgue measure. However, the Lemma [2.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.Thmtheorem2 "Theorem 2.2 (Hopf-Cole Transform). ‣ 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") suggests that by choosing certain classes of Gaussian measure i.e.,μ0=𝒩(et​𝒜𝐱,Qt)\\textit{i}.\\textit{e}.,\\mu\_{0}=\\mathcal{N}(e^{t\\mathcal{A}}\\mathbf{x},Q\_{t}), the Radon-Nikodym density of d​πTd​μ0𝑑subscript𝜋𝑇𝑑subscript𝜇0\\frac{d\\pi\_{T}}{d\\mu\_{0}} and d​μTd​μ0𝑑subscript𝜇𝑇𝑑subscript𝜇0\\frac{d\\mu\_{T}}{d\\mu\_{0}} has explicit form since μ0subscript𝜇0\\mu\_{0} and 𝒩​(0,Q∞)𝒩0subscript𝑄\\mathcal{N}(0,Q\_{\\infty}) is equvalet. Thus, using the chain rule, the terminal cost for any 𝐱∈ℋ𝐱ℋ\\mathbf{x}\\in\\mathcal{H} can be computed as follows:

## 4 Experiments

This section details the experimental setup and the application of the proposed DBFS method for generating functional data. We interpret the data from a functional perspective, known as field representation \[ [68](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib68 ""), [72](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib72 "")\], where data are seen as a finite collection of function evaluations {𝐘​\[𝐩i\],𝐩i}iNsuperscriptsubscript𝐘delimited-\[\]subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑖𝑖𝑁\\{\\mathbf{Y}\[\\mathbf{p}\_{i}\],\\mathbf{p}\_{i}\\}\_{i}^{N}. Here, a function 𝐘𝐘\\mathbf{Y} maps points 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\\mathbf{p}\_{i} from a coordinate space 𝒳𝒳\\mathcal{X} to a signal space 𝒴𝒴\\mathcal{Y}, i.e., 𝐘:𝒳→𝒴:𝐘→𝒳𝒴\\mathbf{Y}:\\mathcal{X}\\to\\mathcal{Y}. Additional experimental details are provided in Appendix [A.9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#A1.SS9 "A.9 Experimental Details ‣ Appendix A Appendix ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces").

### 4.1 Bridge Matching

First, we present empirical results of the infinite-dimensional BM algorithm presented in [3.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S3.SS1 "3.1 Infinite Dimensional Bridge Matching ‣ 3 Simulating Diffusion Bridges in Infinite Dimensional Spaces ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") on 2D data. Here, we assume 𝒳=ℝ2𝒳superscriptℝ2\\mathcal{X}=\\mathbb{R}^{2} and 𝒴=ℝ𝒴ℝ\\mathcal{Y}=\\mathbb{R} or ℝ3superscriptℝ3\\mathbb{R}^{3}.

##### Imputation.

We evaluate our method against recent diffusion-based imputation method where the goal is to infer the conditional distribution p​(𝐘​\[𝐓\]\|𝐘​\[𝐎\])𝑝conditional𝐘delimited-\[\]𝐓𝐘delimited-\[\]𝐎p(\\mathbf{Y}\[\\mathbf{T}\]\|\\mathbf{Y}\[\\mathbf{O}\]) of unobserved grid 𝐘​\[𝐓\]𝐘delimited-\[\]𝐓\\mathbf{Y}\[\\mathbf{T}\] give observations 𝐘​\[𝐎\]𝐘delimited-\[\]𝐎\\mathbf{Y}\[\\mathbf{O}\]. CSDI \[ [61](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib61 "")\] utilizes DDPM \[ [30](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib30 "")\] to learn the reverse process by treating the temporal data 𝐘​\[𝐎\]𝐘delimited-\[\]𝐎\\mathbf{Y}\[\\mathbf{O}\] as a ℝ\|𝐎\|×dsuperscriptℝ𝐎𝑑\\mathbb{R}^{\|\\mathbf{O}\|\\times d} dimensional feature. Extending this, DSDP-GP \[ [6](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib6 "")\] enhances CSDI by incorporating noise derived from a stochastic process, instead of simple Gaussian noise. We maintained the same training setup as these models, including random seeds and the model architecture for control αθsuperscript𝛼𝜃\\alpha^{\\theta} in ( [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E2 "In 2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")). Consistent with their methodology, we employed the Physionet dataset \[ [27](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib27 "")\], which comprises medical time-series data collected on an hourly rate. Since the dataset inherently contains missing values, we selected certain degrees of observed values to create an imputation test set for evaluation. We then reported the results on this test set, varying the degrees of missingness. Table [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S4.T1 "Table 1 ‣ Functional Regression ‣ 4.2 Bayesian Learning ‣ 4 Experiments ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces") shows that we outperform the previous methods even though it solely relies on forward propagation of controlled SDEs in ( [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E9 "In 2.3 Doob’s ℎ-transform for Diffusion Bridges in Hilbert Spaces ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) without denoising procedure.

## 5 Conclusion, Limitation and Broader Societal Impact

In this work, we shed light on the Doob’s hℎh-transform \[ [52](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib52 "")\] exploiting the SOC theory in infinite-dimensional spaces.
By developing a explicit Radon-Nikodym density, we address the challenge posed by the absence of an equivalent to the Lebesgue measure. This allows us to extending previous applications utilized from Doob’s hℎh-transform into function spaces such as resolution-free image translation and functional bayesian posterior sampling.

Compared to the recent infinite-dimensional score-based diffusion model \[ [38](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib38 "")\], our work restricts the coefficients for the stochastic dynamics to be time-independent. This limitation prevents us from defining a noise schedule for the diffusion model \[ [71](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib71 "")\], which may hinder performance improvements. Additionally, since our model can be applied to any functional domain, we have limited our experiments to 1D and 2D domains. We leave the extension of the algorithm to more general domains, such as molecule generation, for future work.

Similar to other works in the literature, our proposed method holds the potential for both beneficial outcomes, such as automated data synthesis, and adverse implications, such as the deep fakes, depending on how it is used. We adhere to ethical standards for using our model in generative AI.

## Appendix A Appendix

### A.1 Related Work

Most diffusion models operate within the framework of time-reversal \[ [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib1 "")\], where the generation process is learned from its corresponding time-reversed SDEs \[ [57](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib57 "")\]. In contrast, diffusion models based on conditioned SDEs, such as diffusion bridges, built upon the theory of Doob’s hℎh-transform, offer a conceptually simpler approach as they solely rely on a forward process. \[ [45](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib45 "")\] proposes generative models with this concept, showing that the mixture of forward diffusion bridge processes effectively transports between couplings of two distributions. \[ [69](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib69 "")\] introduces a family of first hitting diffusion models that generate data with a forward diffusion process at a random first hitting time based on Doob’s hℎh-transform. Combining time-reversal with the hℎh-transform, \[ [42](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib42 "")\] proposes a diffusion bridge process on constrained domains. Moreover, \[ [54](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib54 ""), [46](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib46 "")\] demonstrate that the Schrödinger bridge problem can be solved by an iterative algorithm. \[ [41](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib41 "")\] further generalizes the Schrödinger bridge matching algorithm by introducing an approximation scheme involving a non-trivial running cost. None of these prior works discuss constructing bridge processes outside of Euclidean space. In contrast, our work extends the formulation of Doob’s hℎh-transform into Hilbert space, thereby constructing infinite-dimensional diffusion bridges. This extension allows for the modeling of diffusion bridge processes in function spaces.

### A.5 Deriving Divergence Between Path Measures

Here we present an infinite-dimensional generalization of Girsanov’s theorem \[ [17](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib17 ""), Theorem 10.14\], which plays a crucial role in estimating the divergence between two path measures discussed in Sec [2.4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.SS4 "2.4 Approximating path measures ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces"). The theorem is formulated as follows:

###### Theorem A.4(Girsanov’s Theorem in ℋℋ\\mathcal{H}).

Let γ𝛾\\gamma be a ℋ0subscriptℋ0\\mathcal{H}\_{0}-valued ℱtsubscriptℱ𝑡\\mathcal{F}\_{t}-predictable process such that

|     |     |     |     |

##### Sampling Algorithm.

The sampling algorithm for DBFS in bridge matching, introduced in Section [4.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S4.SS1.SSS0.Px2 "Unpaired Field Transfer. ‣ 4.1 Bridge Matching ‣ 4 Experiments ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces"), is detailed in Algorithm [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#alg3 "Algorithm 3 ‣ Loss calculation for the BM. ‣ A.8 Numerical Integration for DBFS ‣ Appendix A Appendix ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces").

### A.9 Experimental Details

#### A.9.1 Experiment on 2D-Domain

##### Synthetic Experiment.

In a synthetic experiment, we computed the log-probability of p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0} and pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p\_{T} across a uniformly sampled grid of 642superscript64264^{2} points, with each point 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\\mathbf{p}\_{i} ranging within \[−7,7\]2superscript772\[-7,7\]^{2}. For p0subscript𝑝0p\_{0}, the log-probability was generated using an 8-Gaussian mixture model as specified in \[ [63](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib63 "")\]. For pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p\_{T}, we employed the following log-density function:

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | log⁡pT​(𝐩)=−min⁡(∥𝐩−1∥2,∥𝐩−3∥2,∥𝐩−5∥2)0.05.subscript𝑝𝑇𝐩superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐩12superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐩32superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐩520.05\\log p\_{T}(\\mathbf{p})=-\\frac{\\min(\\left\\lVert\\mathbf{p}-1\\right\\rVert^{2},\\left\\lVert\\mathbf{p}-3\\right\\rVert^{2},\\left\\lVert\\mathbf{p}-5\\right\\rVert^{2})}{0.05}. |  | (A.81) |

Training was conducted using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1​e−31𝑒31e-3. The network was trained with a batch size of 24 for a total of 1000 iterations. We set σ=0.2𝜎0.2\\sigma=0.2 in ( [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E1 "In Stochastic Differential Equations in Hilbert Spaces. ‣ 2.1 Preliminaries ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) for this experiment and set 100 discretization steps. We use a single A600060006000 GPU for this experiment.

The control function was parameterized using a 444-layer FNO-2D \[ [36](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib36 "")\], with the cutoff number of Fourier modes set at 888 and each convolution layer having a width of 323232.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630/assets/x3.png)Figure A.1: Transformer-based network architecture.

##### AFHQ Transfer Experiment.

For the AFHQ dataset \[ [14](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib14 "")\]333 [https://github.com/clovaai/stargan-v2](https://github.com/clovaai/stargan-v2 "") under CC BY-NC 4.0 License. , we evaluate proposed BM algorithm between classes dog and cat evaluated on 642superscript64264^{2} grid, where each class contains approximately 5,000 samples. We use the complex Fourier basis for the Hilbert spaces, indexed by k𝑘k and followed 𝒜,Q𝒜𝑄\\mathcal{A},Q as suggested in \[ [22](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib22 "")\]. and set σ=1𝜎1\\sigma=1
We discretize the SDE in to 100100100 steps and opt not using noise-schedule since the SDEs in ( [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#S2.E1 "In Stochastic Differential Equations in Hilbert Spaces. ‣ 2.1 Preliminaries ‣ 2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges ‣ Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces")) have its solution when 𝒜𝒜\\mathcal{A} and σ𝜎\\sigma is time-indenpendent. Therefore we set a constant schedule β=1𝛽1\\beta=1 and Δt=subscriptΔ𝑡absent\\Delta\_{t}= 1e-2. We use Adam optimizer with learning rate of 1e-5 which gradually was decreased by a factor of 0.990.990.99 every iterations. The EMA rate was set to 0.990.990.99. We set batch size of 363636 and trained for 400,000400000400,000 iterations, taking 161616 hours per 100,000100000100,000 steps. We use 444 A600060006000 GPUs for this experiment.

We utilize the network architecture of PerceiverIO \[ [32](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib32 "")\] from public repository444 [https://github.com/lucidrains/perceiver-pytorch](https://github.com/lucidrains/perceiver-pytorch "") under MIT License. to model functional representation. Our choice of this transformer architecture is motivated by its efficiency in evaluating field representations across a large number of grid points and its capability to map arbitrary input arrays to arbitrary output arrays in a domain-agnostic manner. We modified the decoding cross-attention mechanism, inspired by \[ [35](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib35 "")\], we set the output query as the target grid points. The target grid points are transformed as Gaussian Fourier features \[ [60](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib60 "")\].

In practice, we initially feed the evaluations 𝐗​\[𝐩\]𝐗delimited-\[\]𝐩\\mathbf{X}\[\\mathbf{p}\] into a single MLP layer and concatenate it with the Fourier feature embedding of grid points 𝐩𝐩\\mathbf{p} and time t𝑡t, with frequencies of 256 and 64, respectively. This is then fed into the cross-attention layer as key and value, where QKV attention is applied with a latent query value of dimensions 322×512superscript32251232^{2}\\times 512. We consistently set the latent dimension of attention to 512 and use 4 heads for all attention modules, with each head having a dimension of 128.

Sequentially, the latent array is processed through 12 self-attention layers and then fed into another cross-attention layer, where QKV attention is applied again with the transformed target grid points. Finally, a single linear layer maps the 512-dimensional latent array into RBF channels. Our model has approximately 606060M parameters.

The choice of γ𝛾\\gamma is hyper-parameter, we search over the set \[0,01,0.1,0.2,0.5,1.0\]0010.10.20.51.0\[0,01,0.1,0.2,0.5,1.0\] and find optimal value for GP regression. For imputation, we set γ=0.02𝛾0.02\\gamma=0.02 by following \[ [6](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib6 "")\].

For the other test data, we define κ​(𝐩i,𝐩j)=l12​(1+5​d/l2+5​d2/(3​l22))​e​x​p​(−5​d/l2)𝜅subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑙2115𝑑subscript𝑙25superscript𝑑23subscriptsuperscript𝑙22𝑒𝑥𝑝5𝑑subscript𝑙2\\kappa(\\mathbf{p}\_{i},\\mathbf{p}\_{j})=l^{2}\_{1}(1+\\sqrt{5}d/l\_{2}+5d^{2}/(3l^{2}\_{2}))exp(-\\sqrt{5}d/l\_{2}) with d=(∥𝐩i−𝐩j∥)𝑑delimited-∥∥subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑗d=(\\left\\lVert\\mathbf{p}\_{i}-\\mathbf{p}\_{j}\\right\\rVert), l1∼Unif​(0.1,1.0)similar-tosubscript𝑙1Unif0.11.0l\_{1}\\sim\\text{Unif}(0.1,1.0) and l2∼Unif​(0.1,0.6)similar-tosubscript𝑙2Unif0.10.6l\_{2}\\sim\\text{Unif}(0.1,0.6) for Matérn kernel and κ​(𝐩i,𝐩j)=l12​exp⁡(−2​sin2⁡(π​∥𝐩i−𝐩j∥2/p)/l2)𝜅subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑙212superscript2𝜋superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑗2𝑝subscript𝑙2\\kappa(\\mathbf{p}\_{i},\\mathbf{p}\_{j})=l^{2}\_{1}\\exp(-2\\sin^{2}(\\pi\\left\\lVert\\mathbf{p}\_{i}-\\mathbf{p}\_{j}\\right\\rVert^{2}/p)/l\_{2}) with l1∼Unif​(0.1,1.0)similar-tosubscript𝑙1Unif0.11.0l\_{1}\\sim\\text{Unif}(0.1,1.0), l2∼Unif​(0.1,0.6)similar-tosubscript𝑙2Unif0.10.6l\_{2}\\sim\\text{Unif}(0.1,0.6) and p∼Unif​(0.1,0.5)similar-to𝑝Unif0.10.5p\\sim\\text{Unif}(0.1,0.5) for periodic kernel.

The architectures for NP \[ [25](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib25 "")\] and CNP \[ [24](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib24 "")\], we use the same setting as described in \[ [34](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib34 "")\]555 [https://github.com/juho-lee/bnp](https://github.com/juho-lee/bnp "") under MIT License.. In our approach, we adapted the CNP architecture to incorporate a parameterized initial condition 𝐱θsuperscript𝐱𝜃\\mathbf{x}^{\\theta} (add one linear layer to output 𝐱θsuperscript𝐱𝜃\\mathbf{x}^{\\theta}). The total number of parameters is similar across all three models.

##### Physionet Imputation

The Physionet \[ [27](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib27 "")\] contains 400040004000 clinical time series with 353535 variables for 484848 houds from intensive care unit. Following \[ [61](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib61 "")\], we preprocess this datasets to hourly time-sereis which have 484848 time steps. Since the dataset already contains around 80%percent8080\\% of missingness, we randomly choose 10/50/90%1050percent9010/50/90\\% of observed values as test data.

In the imputation experiments, we employed the same experimental setup as \[ [6](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.20630#bib.bib6 "")\]666 [https://github.com/morganstanley/MSML/tree/main/papers/Stochastic\_Process\_Diffusion](https://github.com/morganstanley/MSML/tree/main/papers/Stochastic_Process_Diffusion "") under Apache 2.02.02.0 License. which is slight modification of original CSDI model. In this setup, the Gaussian noise of the DDPM model was replaced with GP noise employing an RBF kernel. Additionally, we adjusted the measurement approach to record the actual elapsed time rather than rounding to the nearest hour, better capturing the inherent timing characteristics of the Physionet dataset. We use a single A600060006000 GPU for this experiment.

html:
Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges in Function Spaces

Byoungwoo Park1, Jungwon Choi1, Sungbin Lim2,3, Juho Lee111footnotemark: 1
KAIST1, Korea University2, LG AI Research3
{bw.park, jungwon.choi, juholee}@kaist.ac.kr,
sungbin@korea.ac.kr Co-corresponding Author
Abstract

Recent advancements in diffusion models and diffusion bridges primarily focus on finite-dimensional spaces, yet many real-world problems necessitate operations in infinite-dimensional function spaces for more natural and interpretable formulations. In this paper, we present a theory of stochastic optimal control (SOC) tailored to infinite-dimensional spaces, aiming to extend diffusion-based algorithms to function spaces. Specifically, we demonstrate how Doob’s hℎh-transform, the fundamental tool for constructing diffusion bridges, can be derived from the SOC perspective and expanded to infinite dimensions. This expansion presents a challenge, as infinite-dimensional spaces typically lack closed-form densities. Leveraging our theory, we establish that solving the optimal control problem with a specific objective function choice is equivalent to learning diffusion-based generative models. We propose two applications: 1) learning bridges between two infinite-dimensional distributions and 2) generative models for sampling from an infinite-dimensional distribution. Our approach proves effective for diverse problems involving continuous function space representations, such as resolution-free images, time-series data, and probability density functions.

1 Introduction

Stochastic Optimal Control (SOC) is designed to steer a noisy system toward a desired state by minimizing a specific cost function. This methodology finds extensive applications across various fields in science and engineering, including rate event simulation [29, 31], stochastic filtering and data assimilation [43, 65, 49], non-convex optimization [9], modeling population dynamics [8, 39]. SOC is also related to diffusion-based sampling methods that are predominant in machine learning literature. Specifically, if we choose the terminal cost of a control problem as the log density ratio between a target distribution and a simple prior distribution, solving the optimal control reduces to learning a diffusion-based generative models [50, 70, 66] built upon the Schrödinger bridge problem [48, 12].

While SOC associated diffusion-based generative models have been well-established for finite-dimensional spaces [5, 10, 11, 41], their theoretical foundations and practical algorithms for infinite-dimensional spaces remain underexplored. There is a growing interest in developing generative models in function spaces. Examples include learning neural operators for partial differential equations (PDEs) [36, 35, 33], interpreting images as discretized functions through implicit neural representations (INRs) [56, 19], and operating in function spaces for Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) [58, 67]. Models that operate in function spaces are more parameter-efficient as they avoid resolution-specific parameterizations. In response to this demand, several extensions of diffusion-based generative models for infinite-dimensional function spaces have been proposed  [47, 37, 28, 38, 22, 3]. However, SOC theory for building diffusion bridges in function spaces is still demanding in the community of generative modeling.

To address these challenges, this work introduces an extension of SOC for diffusion bridges in infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces, particularly focusing on its applications in sampling problems. Specifically, we demonstrate the idea of Doob’s hℎh transform [52, 13] can be derived from SOC theory and extend its formulation into Hilbert spaces. Due to the absence of a density with respect to the Lebesgue measure in infinite-dimensional spaces, building a diffusion bridge between function spaces is a nontrivial task separated from the finite-dimensional cases [46, 54]. To this end, we propose a Radon-Nikodym derivative relative to a specified Gaussian reference measure in Hilbert space. Leveraging the infinite-dimensional Doob’s hℎh transform and SOC, we then formulate diffusion bridge-based sampling algorithms in function spaces.

To demonstrate the applicability of our theory, we present learning algorithms for two representative problems. First, we introduce an infinite-dimensional bridge-matching algorithm as an extension of previous methods [46, 54] into Hilbert spaces, which learns a generative model to bridge two distributions defined in function spaces. As an example, we show that our framework can learn smooth transitions between two image distributions in a resolution-free manner. Second, we propose a simulation-based Bayesian inference algorithm [70, 66] that operates in function space. Instead of directly approximating the target Bayesian posterior, our algorithm learns a stochastic transition from the prior to the posterior within the function space. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by inferring Bayesian posteriors of stochastic processes, such as Gaussian processes. We summarize our contributions as follows:

  • •

    Based on the SOC theory, we derive the Doob’s hℎh-transform in Hilbert spaces. We propose a hℎh function as a Randon-Nikodym derivative with respect to a Gaussian measure in infinite-dimensional space.

  • •

    Based on the infinite-dimensional extension of the Doob’s hℎh transform, we present the diffusion bridge and simulation-based Bayesian inference algorithm in function spaces.

  • •

    We demonstrate our method for various real-world problems involving function spaces, including resolution-free image translation and posterior sampling for stochastic processes.

2 A Foundation on Stochastic Optimal Control for Diffusion Bridges

In this section, we first present a brief introduction to the theory of stochastic optimal control (SOC) in infinite dimensions and the Verification Theorem (Lemma 2.1), which is the key to understanding the theoretical connection between SOC and the diffusion bridges. Then we propose Doob’s hℎh-transform in Hilbert spaces based on the SOC theory (Theorems 2.2 and 2.3).

2.1 Preliminaries

Notation.

2.2 Stochastic Optimal Control in Hilbert Spaces

3 Simulating Diffusion Bridges in Infinite Dimensional Spaces

Leveraging the SOC theory within ℋℋ\mathcal{H}, we show how our approach generalizes existing diffusion-based sampling methods. Specifically, incorporating the relation between controlled SDEs (2) and conditioned SDEs (9), we introduce two learning algorithms that allow us to simulate various diffusion bridge-based sampling algorithms.

4 Experiments

This section details the experimental setup and the application of the proposed DBFS method for generating functional data. We interpret the data from a functional perspective, known as field representation [68, 72], where data are seen as a finite collection of function evaluations {𝐘​[𝐩i],𝐩i}iNsuperscriptsubscript𝐘delimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑖𝑖𝑁\{\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{p}_{i}],\mathbf{p}_{i}\}_{i}^{N}. Here, a function 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} maps points 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}_{i} from a coordinate space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} to a signal space 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}, i.e., 𝐘:𝒳→𝒴:𝐘→𝒳𝒴\mathbf{Y}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y}. Additional experimental details are provided in Appendix A.9.

4.1 Bridge Matching

First, we present empirical results of the infinite-dimensional BM algorithm presented in 3.1 on 2D data. Here, we assume 𝒳=ℝ2𝒳superscriptℝ2\mathcal{X}=\mathbb{R}^{2} and 𝒴=ℝ𝒴ℝ\mathcal{Y}=\mathbb{R} or ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}.

Bridging Field.

We begin by validating our bridge matching algorithm 1 on bridging probability density function within ℋℋ\mathcal{H}. Specifically, we set π0:=δp0assignsubscript𝜋0subscript𝛿subscript𝑝0\pi_{0}:=\delta_{p_{0}} with a ring-shaped density function p0subscript𝑝0p_{0} and πT:=δpTassignsubscript𝜋𝑇subscript𝛿subscript𝑝𝑇\pi_{T}:=\delta_{p_{T}} characterized by a Gaussian mixture density function pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p_{T}. The functions map each grid points 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}_{i} to the probability in 𝒴=ℝ𝒴ℝ\mathcal{Y}=\mathbb{R}. Therefore, both density functions can be represented as their field representations {p0​[𝐩i],𝐩i}iN,{pT​[𝐩i],𝐩i}iNsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝0delimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑖𝑖𝑁superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑖subscript𝐩𝑖𝑖𝑁\{p_{0}[\mathbf{p}_{i}],\mathbf{p}_{i}\}_{i}^{N},\{p_{T}[\mathbf{p}_{i}],\mathbf{p}_{i}\}_{i}^{N}, respectively. Despite the α⋆superscript𝛼⋆\alpha^{\star} is trained on the functions generated from ℙ⋆superscriptℙ⋆\mathbb{P}^{\star} which are evaluated on a coarse grid {𝐩i}i322superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐩𝑖𝑖superscript322\{\mathbf{p}_{i}\}_{i}^{32^{2}}, ℙα⋆superscriptℙsuperscript𝛼⋆\mathbb{P}^{\alpha^{\star}} is capable of producing accurate functional evaluations on a finer grid {𝐩i}i2562superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐩𝑖𝑖superscript2562\{\mathbf{p}_{i}\}_{i}^{256^{2}}. This resolution-invariance property indicates that our method is adept at learning continuous functional representations, rather than merely memorizing the discrete evaluations.

4.2 Bayesian Learning

We validate our Bayesian learning algorithm for modeling functional data. Specifically, we will consider the temporal data as a function. We denote 𝐘​[𝐎]={𝐘​[𝐩i]}i=1|𝐎|𝐘delimited-[]𝐎superscriptsubscript𝐘delimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑖𝑖1𝐎\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}]=\{\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{p}_{i}]\}_{i=1}^{|\mathbf{O}|} as a collection of a function evaluation on a set of 1-dimensional observation grid 𝐎={𝐩i}i|𝐎|𝐎superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐩𝑖𝑖𝐎\mathbf{O}=\{\mathbf{p}_{i}\}_{i}^{|\mathbf{O}|} where 0≤𝐩0<⋯<𝐩|𝐎|≤I0subscript𝐩0⋯subscript𝐩𝐎𝐼0\leq\mathbf{p}_{0}<\cdots<\mathbf{p}_{|\mathbf{O}|}\leq I. We assume that each observed time series approximates a corresponding underlying continuous function 𝐗:ℝ→ℝd:𝐗→ℝsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{X}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} as the number of observations increases i.e.,{𝐘[𝐩i]}i=1|𝐎|→∞≈𝐗\textit{i}.\textit{e}.,\{\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{p}_{i}]\}_{i=1}^{|\mathbf{O}|\to\infty}\approx\mathbf{X}. For given observations 𝐘​[𝐎]𝐘delimited-[]𝐎\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}], our goal is to infer the posterior distribution on some set of unobserved grid 𝐓=[0,I]−𝐎𝐓0𝐼𝐎\mathbf{T}=[0,I]-\mathbf{O} i.e.,ℙ(𝐘[𝐓]|𝐘[𝐎])\textit{i}.\textit{e}.,\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{T}]|\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}]) and therefore modeling distribution over 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} on [0,I].0𝐼[0,I]. Please refer to Section A.9.2 for further details.

Functional Regression

To verify the effectiveness of the proposed DBFS in generating functions in the 1D domain, we conducted regression experiments using synthetic data generated from the Gaussian Process (GP) by following the experimental settings in [34]. The stochastic process begins from the deterministic function 𝐗0α=𝐱0subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝛼0subscript𝐱0\mathbf{X}^{\alpha}_{0}=\mathbf{x}_{0} at t=0𝑡0t=0 and propagates towards the conditional posterior distribution 𝐗Tα∼ℙ​(𝐘​[𝐓]|𝐘​[𝐎])similar-tosubscriptsuperscript𝐗𝛼𝑇ℙconditional𝐘delimited-[]𝐓𝐘delimited-[]𝐎\mathbf{X}^{\alpha}_{T}\sim\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{T}]|\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}]) at t=T𝑡𝑇t=T.

Imputation.

We evaluate our method against recent diffusion-based imputation method where the goal is to infer the conditional distribution p​(𝐘​[𝐓]|𝐘​[𝐎])𝑝conditional𝐘delimited-[]𝐓𝐘delimited-[]𝐎p(\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{T}]|\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}]) of unobserved grid 𝐘​[𝐓]𝐘delimited-[]𝐓\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{T}] give observations 𝐘​[𝐎]𝐘delimited-[]𝐎\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}]. CSDI [61] utilizes DDPM [30] to learn the reverse process by treating the temporal data 𝐘​[𝐎]𝐘delimited-[]𝐎\mathbf{Y}[\mathbf{O}] as a ℝ|𝐎|×dsuperscriptℝ𝐎𝑑\mathbb{R}^{|\mathbf{O}|\times d} dimensional feature. Extending this, DSDP-GP [6] enhances CSDI by incorporating noise derived from a stochastic process, instead of simple Gaussian noise. We maintained the same training setup as these models, including random seeds and the model architecture for control αθsuperscript𝛼𝜃\alpha^{\theta} in (2). Consistent with their methodology, we employed the Physionet dataset [27], which comprises medical time-series data collected on an hourly rate. Since the dataset inherently contains missing values, we selected certain degrees of observed values to create an imputation test set for evaluation. We then reported the results on this test set, varying the degrees of missingness. Table 1 shows that we outperform the previous methods even though it solely relies on forward propagation of controlled SDEs in (9) without denoising procedure.

5 Conclusion, Limitation and Broader Societal Impact

In this work, we shed light on the Doob’s hℎh-transform [52] exploiting the SOC theory in infinite-dimensional spaces. By developing a explicit Radon-Nikodym density, we address the challenge posed by the absence of an equivalent to the Lebesgue measure. This allows us to extending previous applications utilized from Doob’s hℎh-transform into function spaces such as resolution-free image translation and functional bayesian posterior sampling.

Compared to the recent infinite-dimensional score-based diffusion model [38], our work restricts the coefficients for the stochastic dynamics to be time-independent. This limitation prevents us from defining a noise schedule for the diffusion model [71], which may hinder performance improvements. Additionally, since our model can be applied to any functional domain, we have limited our experiments to 1D and 2D domains. We leave the extension of the algorithm to more general domains, such as molecule generation, for future work.

Similar to other works in the literature, our proposed method holds the potential for both beneficial outcomes, such as automated data synthesis, and adverse implications, such as the deep fakes, depending on how it is used. We adhere to ethical standards for using our model in generative AI.

Appendix A Appendix

A.1 Related Work

Most diffusion models operate within the framework of time-reversal [1], where the generation process is learned from its corresponding time-reversed SDEs [57]. In contrast, diffusion models based on conditioned SDEs, such as diffusion bridges, built upon the theory of Doob’s hℎh-transform, offer a conceptually simpler approach as they solely rely on a forward process. [45] proposes generative models with this concept, showing that the mixture of forward diffusion bridge processes effectively transports between couplings of two distributions. [69] introduces a family of first hitting diffusion models that generate data with a forward diffusion process at a random first hitting time based on Doob’s hℎh-transform. Combining time-reversal with the hℎh-transform, [42] proposes a diffusion bridge process on constrained domains. Moreover, [54, 46] demonstrate that the Schrödinger bridge problem can be solved by an iterative algorithm. [41] further generalizes the Schrödinger bridge matching algorithm by introducing an approximation scheme involving a non-trivial running cost. None of these prior works discuss constructing bridge processes outside of Euclidean space. In contrast, our work extends the formulation of Doob’s hℎh-transform into Hilbert space, thereby constructing infinite-dimensional diffusion bridges. This extension allows for the modeling of diffusion bridge processes in function spaces.

A.2.2 Markov Control Formulation

Now, we introduce the following corollary that states the Markov control formulation.

Corollary A.3 (Markov Control [20]).

A.9 Experimental Details

A.9.1 Experiment on 2D-Domain

Synthetic Experiment.

In a synthetic experiment, we computed the log-probability of p0subscript𝑝0p_{0} and pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p_{T} across a uniformly sampled grid of 642superscript64264^{2} points, with each point 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}_{i} ranging within [−7,7]2superscript772[-7,7]^{2}. For p0subscript𝑝0p_{0}, the log-probability was generated using an 8-Gaussian mixture model as specified in [63]. For pTsubscript𝑝𝑇p_{T}, we employed the following log-density function:

log⁡pT​(𝐩)=−min⁡(∥𝐩−1∥2,∥𝐩−3∥2,∥𝐩−5∥2)0.05.subscript𝑝𝑇𝐩superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐩12superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐩32superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐩520.05\log p_{T}(\mathbf{p})=-\frac{\min(\left\lVert\mathbf{p}-1\right\rVert^{2},\left\lVert\mathbf{p}-3\right\rVert^{2},\left\lVert\mathbf{p}-5\right\rVert^{2})}{0.05}. (A.81)

Training was conducted using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1​e−31𝑒31e-3. The network was trained with a batch size of 24 for a total of 1000 iterations. We set σ=0.2𝜎0.2\sigma=0.2 in (1) for this experiment and set 100 discretization steps. We use a single A600060006000 GPU for this experiment.

The control function was parameterized using a 444-layer FNO-2D [36], with the cutoff number of Fourier modes set at 888 and each convolution layer having a width of 323232.

AFHQ Transfer Experiment.

For the AFHQ dataset [14]333https://github.com/clovaai/stargan-v2 under CC BY-NC 4.0 License. , we evaluate proposed BM algorithm between classes dog and cat evaluated on 642superscript64264^{2} grid, where each class contains approximately 5,000 samples. We use the complex Fourier basis for the Hilbert spaces, indexed by k𝑘k and followed 𝒜,Q𝒜𝑄\mathcal{A},Q as suggested in [22]. and set σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1 We discretize the SDE in to 100100100 steps and opt not using noise-schedule since the SDEs in (1) have its solution when 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and σ𝜎\sigma is time-indenpendent. Therefore we set a constant schedule β=1𝛽1\beta=1 and Δt=subscriptΔ𝑡absent\Delta_{t}= 1e-2. We use Adam optimizer with learning rate of 1e-5 which gradually was decreased by a factor of 0.990.990.99 every iterations. The EMA rate was set to 0.990.990.99. We set batch size of 363636 and trained for 400,000400000400,000 iterations, taking 161616 hours per 100,000100000100,000 steps. We use 444 A600060006000 GPUs for this experiment.

We utilize the network architecture of PerceiverIO [32] from public repository444https://github.com/lucidrains/perceiver-pytorch under MIT License. to model functional representation. Our choice of this transformer architecture is motivated by its efficiency in evaluating field representations across a large number of grid points and its capability to map arbitrary input arrays to arbitrary output arrays in a domain-agnostic manner. We modified the decoding cross-attention mechanism, inspired by [35], we set the output query as the target grid points. The target grid points are transformed as Gaussian Fourier features [60].

In practice, we initially feed the evaluations 𝐗​[𝐩]𝐗delimited-[]𝐩\mathbf{X}[\mathbf{p}] into a single MLP layer and concatenate it with the Fourier feature embedding of grid points 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} and time t𝑡t, with frequencies of 256 and 64, respectively. This is then fed into the cross-attention layer as key and value, where QKV attention is applied with a latent query value of dimensions 322×512superscript32251232^{2}\times 512. We consistently set the latent dimension of attention to 512 and use 4 heads for all attention modules, with each head having a dimension of 128.

Sequentially, the latent array is processed through 12 self-attention layers and then fed into another cross-attention layer, where QKV attention is applied again with the transformed target grid points. Finally, a single linear layer maps the 512-dimensional latent array into RBF channels. Our model has approximately 606060M parameters.

For testing, we evaluated the trained models using 3,000 batches, each consisting of 16 samples. We report the mean and standard deviation for five runs. We a single A600060006000 GPU for this experiment.

The architectures for NP [25] and CNP [24], we use the same setting as described in [34]555https://github.com/juho-lee/bnp under MIT License.. In our approach, we adapted the CNP architecture to incorporate a parameterized initial condition 𝐱θsuperscript𝐱𝜃\mathbf{x}^{\theta} (add one linear layer to output 𝐱θsuperscript𝐱𝜃\mathbf{x}^{\theta}). The total number of parameters is similar across all three models.

Physionet Imputation

The Physionet [27] contains 400040004000 clinical time series with 353535 variables for 484848 houds from intensive care unit. Following [61], we preprocess this datasets to hourly time-sereis which have 484848 time steps. Since the dataset already contains around 80%percent8080\% of missingness, we randomly choose 10/50/90%1050percent9010/50/90\% of observed values as test data.

In the imputation experiments, we employed the same experimental setup as [6]666https://github.com/morganstanley/MSML/tree/main/papers/Stochastic_Process_Diffusion under Apache 2.02.02.0 License. which is slight modification of original CSDI model. In this setup, the Gaussian noise of the DDPM model was replaced with GP noise employing an RBF kernel. Additionally, we adjusted the measurement approach to record the actual elapsed time rather than rounding to the nearest hour, better capturing the inherent timing characteristics of the Physionet dataset. We use a single A600060006000 GPU for this experiment.
